The spelling with â€œuâ€ is from the Southwest, while the pronunciation with /aÉª/ is from the East Midlands.

entries.meaning: Something which is bought; a purchase.
examples: At only $30, the second-hand kitchen table was a great buy.

verbs.description: buy (third-person singular simple present buys, present participle buying, simple past bought, past participle bought or (rare, dialectal) boughten)

entries.meaning: (transitive, ditransitive) To obtain (something) in exchange for money or goods.
examples: I'm going to buy my father something nice for his birthday.

entries.meaning: (transitive, ditransitive) To obtain, especially by some sacrifice.
examples: I've bought material comfort by foregoing my dreams.
You just bought yourself an assault charge!

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To suffer consequences for (something) through being deprived of something; to pay for (something one has done).

examples: He tried to buy me with gifts, but I wouldn't give up my beliefs.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be equivalent to in value.
examples: The dollar doesn't buy as much as it used to.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) to accept as true; to believe
examples: I'm not going to buy your stupid excuses anymore!

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a purchase or purchases, to treat (for a drink, meal or gift)
examples: Let's go out for dinner. I'm buying.

entries.meaning: (poker slang, transitive) To make a bluff, usually a large one.
examples: Smith tried to buy the pot on the river with a huge bluff
